text: number 21, John chapter number 21 this evening, and we'll use this passage of Scripture as a springboard into our message this evening. We find that Thomas was not there, according to verse number 24, the Bible says, but Thomas, one of the 12, called Didymus, was not with them when Jesus came. And they told them, they told Thomas about seeing the Lord, and he said that he would not believe, and so on and so forth, but you find that in verse number 26, it says, and after eight days again, His disciples were within, and Thomas with them, then came Jesus, the doors being shut, and stood in the midst and said, Peace be unto you. Then saith He to Thomas, Reach thither thy finger, and behold My hands, and reach hither thy hand, and thrust it into My side, and be not faithless, but believing. The text that I wanted to use this evening is our springboard here in verses 28 and 29. Notice what Thomas says in verse number 28, and Thomas answered and said unto Him, My Lord and my God. Jesus saith unto him, Thomas, because thou hast seen Me, thou hast believed. Blessed are they that have not seen, and yet have believed. Last week, we examined Matthew chapter number 16, and we looked at that question that Jesus asked the disciples, Whom do men say that I am? And of course, we looked at that passage of Scripture, and I mentioned this last week, that the question that was asked by Jesus to the disciples is just as important today as it's ever been. The confusion of the people that we find in Matthew chapter number 16, remember the disciples say, well, some think that you're John the Baptist, or Isaiah, or Jeremiah, or one of the prophets, and there was confusion amongst the people with regard to who Jesus is, who He was, and we find that that confusion still exists today. We understand that Paul said to the believers there in Corinth in 2 Corinthians chapter number 4 that the God of this world hath blinded the minds of them which believe not, and we have the responsibility of preaching the gospel and giving the gospel, and we understand that we must know who Christ is, but we must be able to speak to those that we come into contact with with regard to who is Jesus. We understood that though there was confusion amongst the people, that Peter answered with great confidence, and he proclaimed, thou art the Christ, the Son of the living God. And what a powerful declaration that we see by Peter in that text of Scripture. And I think about this as I see Thomas' response in verse number 28, when Thomas says, my Lord and my God. And when we understand who Jesus is, when we study the doctrine of Christ as we've entered into as of last Wednesday evening, and we think about the person of Christ and who He is, God in flesh, if I were to title the message this evening, and I'm sure it's going to be a two-part message, I would simply entitle it this, Jesus is all the world to me. And there's a song with that title, Jesus is all the world to me, and the songwriter said this, Jesus is all the world to me, my life, my joy, my all. He is my strength from day to day, without Him I would fall. When I am sad, to Him I go, no other one can cheer me so. When I am sad, He makes me glad, He's my friend. Jesus is all the world to me, my friend in trial sore. I go to Him for blessings, and He gives them o'er and o'er. He sends the sunshine and the rain, He sends the harvest, golden grain. Sunshine and rain, harvest of grain, He's my friend. Jesus is all the world to me, and true to Him I'll be. Oh, how could I this friend deny, when He's so true to me. Following Him I know I'm right, He watches o'er me day and night. Following Him by day and night, He's my friend. Jesus is all the world to me, I want no better friend. I trust Him now, I trust Him when life's fleeting days shall end. Beautiful life with such a friend, beautiful life that has no end. Eternal life, eternal joy, He's my friend. And I would echo what the songwriter said in that song that I just read. Jesus is all the world to me, I'm so thankful. The word of God reveals to us who Jesus is, and that we have been privileged as believers to be in a place where someone at some point brought the gospel to us. Whether you're the first believer in your family or whether your parents were introduced to the gospel or your grandparents or however far you dig down, someone brought the gospel to your family. And you have the privilege of knowing through this precious book who Jesus is. And what a blessing because there are countless numbers of people around the globe that are blinded with regard to the question, who is Jesus, who is He? Not only are those that are blinded, but we find that in a world where there are over 7 billion people, a percentage of them have never even heard the name of Jesus, yet even hearing the gospel. And how privileged we are, and we find that Thomas is my Lord and my God. Jesus says, because thou hast seen me, thou hast believed. And then think of this, the latter part of verse number 29. Blessed are they that have not seen and yet have believed. I've not seen him, but I believe the record that he has given us, and I am so thankful for the word of God. Why is it that Jesus is all the world to me? Well, I'm sure there's plenty of answers that we could give to that question, but I've tried to categorize it into five particular areas this evening. And he arose and rebuked the wind and said unto the sea, peace, be still, and the wind ceased, and there was a great calm, and he said unto them, why are you so fearful? How is it that you have no faith? And they feared exceedingly and said one to another, what manner of man is this, that even the wind and the sea obey him? He's God. He's God. And we find that as we look at this portion of scripture, again, it's a familiar portion of scripture. In fact, if you've been in church for any length of time, I'm sure if you were in Sunday school as a child, you probably heard a Bible account, a teacher that taught about Jesus calming the sea. And it's a familiar Bible account, but I hope this evening that maybe we could put ourselves with the disciples just for a moment into that ship and see how fearful they were with regard to the certainty of tragedy because of the storm that had raised up, and they were fearful, and they said, master, carest thou not that we perish? And I mean, to see the Lord Jesus Christ walk out and to say, peace, be still, and immediately there was a calm. That's amazing. And sometimes I believe that one of the dangers for us as the people of God and the longer that we walk with the Lord is sometimes these things can just become commonplace. Oh yeah, we know about that. We know that he calmed this. But we think about the power of our Lord. Why is it that I would say Jesus is all the world to me? Number one, because of who he is. He's God. Number two, because of his mighty power. And I think about the power of God. Listen, it is unlimited. He can calm the storm in your life. He can calm the seas that are raging in your life. And we think about the power of God over disease and sickness and all of those things. And we understand this evening that when we live here in this 21st century and we're dealing with all of the difficulties and adversities that we deal with, that we must be mindful of the mighty power of our Lord and Savior, Jesus Christ. He says this before he would ascend to heaven in Matthew chapter 28. Look over there with me. We'll finish with this portion of scripture as we think about the mighty power of the Lord. And we think about this. Of course, we often reference the Great Commission and we should because it is the responsibility of the child of God to proclaim the gospel to a lost and dying world. Jesus came in verse number 18 of Matthew 28 and he spake unto them. And notice what he says. All power is given unto me in heaven and in earth. He didn't say some power. He didn't say most power. He said, all power is given unto me in heaven and in earth. Notice in verse number 19, it says, go ye therefore and teach all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father and the Son of the Holy Ghost, teaching them to observe all things whatsoever I have commanded you. And lo, I am with you all way, even unto the end of the world, amen. I mean, this passage of scripture has so much great truth in it. But as we focus upon the mighty power of the Lord, we see that he says to these disciples, he will soon be, if you look at the timeline and you look at Matthew 28 and you couple it with Acts chapter number one and giving the last of the Great Commission, then the Ascension, you can read Luke 22 as well and kind of see what's going on there with this record, excuse me, Luke 24, and see the Ascension of the Lord. And these disciples would hear the Lord Jesus Christ say, all power is given unto me in heaven and in earth. Go ye therefore and teach all nations. And he gives that Great Commission. And so he kind of, the book ends, if you will, of the Great Commission. On the front end of it is the fact that he says, all power is given unto me. On the back of the commission, he says, I am with you all way, even unto the end of the world. Now think about that. We have this responsibility, this commission to go, but the Lord in his declaration and giving this commission, he says, I have all power and I'll be with you. Isn't that precious? Why is Jesus all the world to you? I hope that you would say, as the songwriter said, Jesus is all the world to me. And I have three more reasons that I'll give you next week as to why he is all the world to me, but when we start this and evaluate the scriptures, I would say number one, because of who he is, and number two, because of his mighty power. Let's pray. Father, we love you. We thank you for loving us. Thank you for the word of God. Thank you for the truth that is given to us in thy word with regard to the life and ministry of the Lord Jesus Christ. I thank you for the truth of the incarnation, for the truth of your word with regard to the purpose of Christ's birth, that it was prophesied and it was fulfilled. And we find that the purpose was to go to that cruel cross, to suffer and bleed and die. We thank you for the opportunity to look at these portions of scripture this evening with regard to the person of Jesus Christ, with regard to the power of Jesus Christ. God, I pray that our hearts have been encouraged in these few moments of studying thy word, to understand that you indeed are God and that you do possess all power and that you've promised to be with us. I pray that we would go in the power of the Holy Spirit of God. And I pray that we would walk with thee. Lord, even as we sang these wonderful songs this evening, as you're all on the... an altar living for Jesus. Oh, when we understand who You are, when we can answer that question that we examined from Matthew 16 last week, and when we can understand that You're all the world to us because of who You are, because of the things that You've done, because of what You continue to do and how You continue to work, that we would live for You. That we would seek to please You and honor You through all that we say and do. Lord, we ask that You'd bless our time of prayer. We thank You for the privilege of prayer. We thank You that You're a God who hears and answers prayer. We pray that You'd meet with us and bless our time. For it's in Christ's name we pray, Amen.
